title: Benchmarking Zero-Shot Facial Emotion Annotation with Large Language Models: A Multi-Class and Multi-Frame Approach in DailyLife
author: He Zhang (College of Information Sciences and Technology, Penn State University), Xinyi Fu (The Future Laboratory, Tsinghua University), ...
relevance_why: This paper leverages large language models (LLMs) for emotion annotation, which could inspire similar methodologies in audio and speech processing tasks, particularly in emotion recognition in audio.
background: The task involves automated emotion annotation in video data using a large language model without prior training specific to the task.
contribution: This paper introduces a multi-frame approach to improve emotion annotation accuracy in videos, achieving up to 65% average precision for simpler three-class emotion classification.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods for emotion recognition often rely on domain-specific models that require extensive training data.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work utilizes zero-shot capabilities of LLMs, allowing effective emotion classification without prior task-specific training.

key_innovation: Employs a zero-shot approach using a large language model to automatically annotate emotions in video frames, which is notably cost-effective.
real_world_impact: The findings could enhance emotion recognition systems in real-world applications, reducing the reliance on extensive labeled datasets and human annotators.
limitations: The model exhibits reduced performance with complex seven-class emotion tasks and struggles with accurately classifying subtle emotional distinctions.

new_terms.zero-shot learning: **Zero-shot learning** refers to a machine learning approach where a model is able to make predictions about classes that were not explicitly present in the training data.
new_terms.emotion taxonomy: **Emotion taxonomy** is a classification scheme that categorizes emotions into distinct groups or labels, such as the seven classes used in this study.
